title: Air Pollution at Kot Lakhpat
description:
Factories and small industries release unfiltered smoke containing fine particulate matter. Crop residue burning from surrounding rural areas adds to the smog layer. Causes severe eye, throat, and lung irritation.
Increases asthma and cardiovascular problems.
Reduces visibility on roads, increasing accidents.
Students and workers face frequent respiratory illness during winter.

title: scarcity of green spaces
description:
Urban expansion replaced parks and open fields with dense housing.
vegetation drop of ~40% in 15 years.
Daytime surface temperature 3–5 °C higher than nearby greener areas.

title: Brick kiln clusters around outskirts
description: The Ravi River receives untreated industrial waste and sewage from northern Lahore. Reduced vegetation and dark river patches due to chemical runoff. Polluted water contaminates nearby crops and fish, directly impacting livelihoods and food safety.

title: waste issue in mehmood booti
location: Mehmood Booti area, Composting Facility zone
description: Mehmood Booti was Lahore’s first official landfill, now overflowing. Uncontrolled waste burning releases methane and toxic gases due to open fires. This affects air quality and groundwater. Nearby communities report frequent respiratory issues.

title: Noise & Infrastructure Issues
location: Circular Road Rail Zone (31.5853° N, 74.3724° E)
description: Trains crossing through dense residential areas generate continuous noise and vibration, measured up to 95 dB. The aging rail tracks and lack of barriers worsen the disturbance. Chronic noise pollution can cause sleep disorders, stress, and hypertension among nearby residents.

title: Air Pollution due to industrialization
location: Kot Lakhpat Industrial Area (31.4673° N, 74.3542° E)
description: Satellite imagery (e.g., NASA MODIS Aerosol Optical Depth) often shows thick haze over Lahore during winter, especially near Kot Lakhpat’s industrial belt. Factories emit large volumes of PM2.5 and PM10 particles without proper filtration. The air becomes toxic, worsening asthma, eye irritation, and lung diseases. On certain days, Lahore’s AQI exceeds 400–600, one of the world’s highest levels.
